member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Brush
member.summary: Represents an abstract base class for different types of brushes.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.SealableBase
member.summary: A base class providing basic functionality of the interface.
member.remarks: When deriving from this class, it is up to the programmer to call method from within any properties or methods that could change the instance of the class.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.ISealable
member.summary: An interface allowing a class to be sealed to prevent further modifications.
member.remarks: This interface should be implemented on classes where there is a need to make an instance immutable, such as a . A typical use case of this would be maintaining a collection of brushes where the hash key needs to remain the same.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.ISealable.Seal
member.summary: Makes the instance immutable. Any attempts to modify properties or members will result in an exception.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.ISealable.IsSealed
member.summary: Gets whether the instance has been sealed through the method.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.SealableBase.Seal
member.summary: Makes the instance immutable. Any attempts to modify properties or members will result in an exception.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.SealableBase.VerifyNotSealed(Infragistics.Documents.ISealable)
member.summary: Throws an exception if the specified instance is sealed.
member.remarks: This method should be used when verifying whether an instance is mutable and therefore would allow the alteration of any aspects of the class.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.SealableBase.IsSealed
member.summary: Gets whether the instance has already been sealed through the method.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Brush.Clone
member.summary: Returns a copy of the brush.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Brush.Type
member.summary: Gets the of this brush.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.DirectBrush
member.summary: Represents an abstract base class for direct or absolute types of brushes.

remarks.p: Direct brushes can be used when the bounds of the region that will be filled are known. For most situations, using a will suffice because it will be converted to the appropriate DirectBrush internally when the is published. When the bounds and position of an element are known, such as an element with a fixed height and width in a or in the method, a direct brush can allow for an additional degree of control.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.IndirectBrush
member.summary: Represents an abstract base class for indirect or floating types of brushes.

remarks.p: An indirect brush will suffice for most situations since it is not a requirement to know the position and bounds of the element that is being filled by the brush. Any brushes of this type will be converted to a when elements need to be rendered, but do not require the programmer to take specific action.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.IndirectBrush.SetBounds(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Bounds an indirect brush and creates a correspondent direct brush.
member.param: X-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the bounding rectangle.
Y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the bounding rectangle.
member.returns: Direct brush.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlendEntry
member.summary: Represents an entry in a .

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlendEntry.#ctor(Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Color,System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A color to use at the corresponding offset along the gradient line.
A position along the gradient line.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlendEntry.Clone
member.summary: Creates a copy of this entry.
member.returns: A copy of this entry.

member.summary: Compares this entry to the specified one.
member.param: A reference to the entry to compare with.
member.returns: A boolean value indicating whether the entries are equal.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlendEntry.Color
member.summary: Gets or sets the color to use at the corresponding offset along the gradient line.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlendEntry.Position
member.summary: Gets or sets the position along the gradient line.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlend
member.summary: Represents a color blend.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlend.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A object used to initialize the instance.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlend.Add(Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Color,System.Single)
member.summary: Adds an entry to the blend.
member.param: A color to use at the corresponding position along the gradient line.
A position along the gradient line.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlend.Clone
member.summary: Creates a copy of this color blend.
member.returns: A copy of this color blend.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlend.Complete
member.summary: Completes this blend with the boundary entries.
member.returns: A completed entry.
member.remarks: If a ColorBlend's last position is not 1, then it will be completed by adding a new using the last color already in the blend with a position of 1.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlend.Insert(System.Int32,Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Color,System.Single)
member.summary: Inserts an entry into the blend.
member.param: A color to use at the corresponding offset along the gradient line.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlend.Equals(Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlend)
member.summary: Compares this blend to the specified one.
member.param: A reference to the blend to compare with.
member.returns: A boolean value indicating whether the blends are equal.

member.summary: Makes the instance immutable. Any attempts to modify properties or members will result in an exception.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.ColorBlend.IsSealed
member.summary: Gets whether the instance has been sealed through the method.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Brushes
member.summary: Implements a set of predefined brushes.
member.remarks: All of the predefined brushes are sealed through the interface. This prevents any of the brushes from being altered so that they maintain their named colors.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Brushes.GetBrush(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a object by its name.
member.param: A string that is the name of a predefined brush.
member.returns: The object.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.JPEGCompressor
member.summary: Represents an implementation of a JPEG compressor.

remarks.p: JPEG is a lossy compression algorithm whose quality settings are measured on a scale of 0-100.

Note: Since this compression algorithm is inherently lossy, it is possible that the transparency mechanism within this assembly, such as through , will seem to partially function. This is because not all of the colors will necessarily be exactly what they were originally (i.e. White (255, 255, 255) may be (253, 255, 255)), so when checking the pixel to see if it is the transparent color specified, it will not be considered a match. In this scenario, it is recommended to use .

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: The default quality setting of is set to 75. For more precise control, use either the overload.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Image.#ctor(System.Drawing.Image,Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Color)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A used to initialize the instance.
The used to replace any pixels in the image whose alpha level is 0.

remarks.p: Since PDF documents do not support per-pixel transparency, all pixels have the alpha channel stripped. In the case of a pixels whose value is , stripping the alpha bit will result in black being used instead, which can be unsesireable in many cases. Specifying this a map color allows a choice in which color will be used with an alpha level of 0.
Using the transparent map color is useful when dealing with a in that calling with the string representation of the map color will allow those pixels to be transparent within the document.

Note: If there are areas where the transparent color is not applied, generally close to an area where there are several other colors, it may be because the used does not correctly maintain all of the pixels, due to compression, so what was once the transparent color to use could be altered by a couple bits. This can happen with , for example. If this is the case, try using

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Pen.MiterLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets the line miter limit.
member.remarks: The miter limit determins at what angle lines are cut-off when joining two together. This essentially determines how "pointy" the line joins are before they are cut-off. Setting a higher value will allow a larger range of "pointiness".

member.summary: Gets or sets the of the pen.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Pen.Width
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the pen.
member.remarks: Similar to how the is setup, the width of a is measured in generic units, which are then used with the unit type that is set on the underlying graphics object. By default, this unit of measurement is points.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Segment.ISegmentHeader
member.summary: Represents a segment header.

remarks.p: When multiple headers are added to a segment, each page will use the next header in the internal list, cycling back to the beginning of the list after the end is reached. Mathematically, think of the header used as [page #] mod [# headers].

As an example, assume that there are two headers in the segment:
Page 1: First Header
Page 2: Second Header
Page 3: First Header
...
Note: A header can be excluded from being repeated through the property

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A objects that represents the default style for all borders.
member.remarks: Specifying a single pen will cause all borders to use the same instance of a . Consequently, changing the of any individual border will affect every border. In order to change individual border colors, a new instance of the Border class needs to be assigned to the border in question.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Borders.#ctor(Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Pen,System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A objects that represents the default style for all borders.
A float value indicating the radius of the corners.
member.remarks: Specifying a single pen will cause all borders to use the same instance of a . Consequently, changing the of any individual border will affect every border. In order to change individual border colors, a new instance of the class needs to be assigned to the border that needs to be changed.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Borders.#ctor(Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Pen,Infragistics.Documents.Graphics.Pen)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A objects that represents the default style for horizontal borders.
A objects that represents the default style for vertical borders.
member.remarks: By specifying a horizontal pen and a vertical pen, a single border object will be shared between each horizontal border and each vertical border. Consequently, if the is changed on one of these borders, the other will also be affected. To work around this, a new instance of the class needs to be created and assigned to the border that needs to be changed.

remarks.p: The class is abstract, meaning that a new instance cannot be created. Additionally, this abstract class does not have any properties aside from . The instantiable classes are , , and .

remarks.p: As a lightweight counterpart to , a QuickImage element is not as customizable, including the lack of ability to apply a preset pattern.
The following properties are on an IImage element that do not have corresponding versions within a QuickImage element:

member.summary: Gets or sets the transparent color of the image.

member.summary: Gets or sets the alpha value of the image.

member.summary: Gets or sets a boolean value indicating whether to stretch the image to fit the container by its width.

member.summary: Gets or sets the spacing between elements.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.Report.IQuickImage.Parent
member.summary: Gets the parent associated with the image.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.IMetafileLoader
member.summary: Provides an interface to provide custom loading of metafiles when publishing a report from an XML file.

remarks.p: Note: The loader will only be used when the Source attribute of the Metafile in an XML file starts with "Loader:". Any subsequent text following this prefix will be passed in as the path parameter of the method.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.IMetafileLoader.Load(System.String)
member.summary: Loads a metafile from the specified path.
member.param: A path to the metafile to load.
member.returns: A object.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.IFontLoader
member.summary: Provides an interface to provide custom loading of fonts when publishing a report from an XML file.

remarks.p: Note: The loader will only be used when the Source attribute of the Font in an XML file starts with "Loader:". Any subsequent text following this prefix will be passed in as the path parameter of the method.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.IFontLoader.Load(System.String)
member.summary: Loads a font.
member.param: A path to the font to load.
member.returns: A object.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.IImageLoader
member.summary: Provides an interface to provide custom loading of images when publishing a report from an XML file.

remarks.p: Note: The loader will only be used when the Source attribute of the Image in an XML file starts with "Loader:". Any subsequent text following this prefix will be passed in as the path parameter of the method.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.IImageLoader.Load(System.String)
member.summary: Loads an image from the specified path.
member.param: A path to the image to load.
member.returns: A object.

When accessing this property, the returned object should be cast to the appropriate derived type, while when setting this property, the constructor of the desired type should be used.
The instantiable classes are , , and .

members.member:
Represents a quick table element. .
As a lightweight counterpart to , a QuickTable is not as customizable. The following properties are on an ITable that do not have corresponding versions within a QuickTable element:
Additionally, there are no patterns that can be applied to a QuickTable for quick reuse, such as can be done with a . Further differences can be found within the way that a operates.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Segment.ISegmentFooter
member.summary: Represents a segment footer.

remarks.p: When multiple footers are added to a segment, each page will use the next footer in the internal list, cycling back to the beginning of the list after the end is reached. Mathematically, think of the footer used as [page #] mod [# footers].

As an example, assume that there are two footers in the segment:
Page 1: First Footer
Page 2: Second Footer
Page 3: First Footer
...
Note: A footer can be excluded from being repeated through the property

member.summary: Creates a new header object that implements the interface and adds it to the internal collection of objects.
member.returns: An object that implements the interface.

remarks.p: When multiple headers are added to a segment, each page will use the next header in the internal list, cycling back to the beginning of the list after the end is reached. Mathematically, think of the header used as [page #] mod [# headers].

As an example, assume that there are two headers in the segment:
Page 1: First Header
Page 2: Second Header
Page 3: First Header
...
Note: A header can be excluded from being repeated through the property

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.ICallback
member.summary: Represents a callback interface.
member.remarks: A callback can be used when loading a object from XML. There are three tags that will trigger the various callback functions where each tag has a corresponding "On*" callback.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.ICallback.OnMergeCode(System.String)
member.summary: Handles merge codes.
member.param: A name of a merge code.
member.returns: The value for the merge code.
member.remarks: This callback is triggered when a tag with the format "<MergeCode Name=?/>" is encountered in the XML, where "?" is the name. Generaly, this callback would be used when a value should be dynamically inserted into a placeholder during the loading of the report.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.ICallback.OnContainer(Infragistics.Documents.Report.IContainer)
member.summary: Handles containers.
member.remarks: This callback is triggered when a tag with the format "<Container Name=?/>" is encountered in the XML, where "?" is the name.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.ICallback.OnInjector(System.String,Infragistics.Documents.Report.Text.IText,Infragistics.Documents.Report.Text.Style,Infragistics.Documents.Report.Text.Hyperlink)
member.summary: Handles injectors.
member.param: A object to inject with the content.
member.remarks: This callback is triggered when a tag with the format "<Injector Name=?/>" is encountered in the XML, where "?" is the name. Using this callback provides more flexibility than the method in that additional elements can be added to the containing element.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Flow.IFlow
member.summary: Represents a layout element that positions its contents by rows or columns.

remarks.p: A flow element numbers each content element and arranges them sequentially by either rows or columns. Elements are layed out as long as there is room on the page and within the bounds specified on the flow element.

The way that content is positioned is dependant on whether any s exist within the flow element:
Columns: When one or more columns are added through the method, content will be sequentially layed out from top-to-bottom and left-to right. In other words, content will be aligned from the top of the first column to the bottom of the first column; if there is additional content, the same process will be repeated on the subsequent column.
Rows: If no columns have been added through the AddColumn method, content will be aligned left-to-right and top-to-bottom, where the width is determined by the Width property of the element, if available, and its total height. In other words, the first element will be positioned at the top left of the flow element with as many elements aligned to the right as will fit; when there is no more room, the same process will be continued on the following line.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Table.ITable
member.summary: Represents a table element.
member.remarks: Each table row is independent and can have as many cells as required. This allows the simulation of colspan properties and helps to create very complex symmetric or asymmetric layouts. This is different from a element where a cell's width is determined by the width of the corresponding and a cell has its own colspan and rowspan properties.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Section.ISectionFooter
member.summary: Represents a section footer.

remarks.p: When multiple footers are added to a section, each page will use the next footer in the internal list, cycling back to the beginning of the list after the end is reached. Mathematically, think of the footer used as [page #] mod [# footers].

As an example, assume that there are two footers in the section:
Page 1: First Footer
Page 2: Second Footer
Page 3: First Footer
...
Note: A footer can be excluded from being repeated through the property

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Section.ISection
member.summary: Represents a low-level element to which most other elements can be added.
member.remarks: As many Section elements can be added to a object as required. Each section can have its own collection of headers, footers, stationaries, and decorations, in addition to being able to set page sizes, backgrounds, borders and other properties.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Section.ISection.AddHeader
member.summary: Creates a new header object that implements the interface and adds it to the internal collection of objects.
member.returns: An object that implements the interface.

remarks.p: When multiple headers are added to a section, each page will use the next header in the internal list, cycling back to the beginning of the list after the end is reached. Mathematically, think of the header used as [page #] mod [# headers].

As an example, assume that there are two headers in the section:
Page 1: First Header
Page 2: Second Header
Page 3: First Header
...
Note: A header can be excluded from being repeated through the property

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Section.ISection.AddFooter
member.summary: Creates a new footer object that implements the interface and adds it to the internal collection of objects.
member.returns: An object that implements the interface.

remarks.p: When multiple footers are added to a section, each page will use the next footer in the internal list, cycling back to the beginning of the list after the end is reached. Mathematically, think of the footer used as [page #] mod [# footers].

As an example, assume that there are two footers in the section:
Page 1: First Footer
Page 2: Second Footer
Page 3: First Footer
...
Note: A footer can be excluded from being repeated through the property

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Section.IStationery
member.summary: Represents a section stationery.
member.remarks: A Stationary element provides a means of adding content that can be repeated across multiple pages. An example of where this could be useful is when wanting to draw standard text, such as the words "Confidential" across a portion of the page but not within a header or footer object.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Section.PageNumbering
member.summary: Represents page numbering attributes.

remarks.p: This element does not automatically shift other content elements to prevent overlapping. The best way to prevent this is to set spacings on the page, such as through .

In order to determine how much spacing to leave, the size of the font used for the page numberings can be used, available through the property, checking the . Additionally, extra padding may be added to prevent the page numbering from lining up directly against a content element.

member.summary: Gets or sets a object that defines the style of the numbers.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Section.PageNumbering.Template
member.summary: Gets or sets the template for the numbers.
member.remarks:
There are three valid replacement tokens for use as a template, all of which are case-sensitive:
[Page #] - The page number of the current page.
[LastPageInSection] - The page number that the last page of the current section is on.
[TotalPages] - The total number of pages in the entire document.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Documents.Report.Text.IText.AddTarget(System.String)
member.summary: Adds a target element to the content of the text.
member.remarks: A target is used in combination with with a . In order for the index to see a word on multiple pages, the word needs to be added as a target for each text element that it belongs to. The index is build based on all of the targets in the document.

When accessing this property, the returned object should be cast to the appropriate derived type, while when setting this property, the constructor of the desired type should be used.
The instantiable classes are , , and .
